name: SiN Episodes: Emergence
description: You are John Blade, commander of HardCorps, an elite security force dedicated to protecting the people of Freeport City. Four years have passed since your first battle with Elexis Sinclaire, a beautiful, brilliant, and ruthless scientist who is out to remake humanity according to her own twisted vision.
minimum_requirements: 1.2 GHz Processor, 256MB RAM, DirectX 7 level graphics card, Windows XP, Mouse, Keyboard, Internet Connection Recommended: 2.4 GHz Processor, 512MB RAM, DirectX 9 level graphics card, Windows XP, Mouse, Keyboard, Internet Connection

reviews.review_text: Buy this because Inside Gaming... BLADE!

I do not understand why the store page disappeared for this title. I wonder if anybody can see / read my review of this game.  SIN was an interesting FPS at the end of the '90s. It had a lot of scripted events and some really good action sequences. The game was also very difficult (or at least this is how I remember). I guess a lot of people played Half Life instead so perhaps not many gamers remember this title.   Emergence meant to be a sequel but with the new Source engine developed by Valve. The creators wanted to release follow-up episodes but it seems Emergency was not successful enough for this to happen. It is a pity as the game is quite good. It can be completed in a mere 3-4 hours due to its shortness, though.  I played its demo years ago so when it was offered with a discount bundled with the original game (released in 1998) I instantly grabbed it.  PS: It seems the store page is up and running so there's no issue with this.

You wouldn't think it looking at the game right now but once upon a time I used this game as a way to test my new PCs. Not because it was ever demanding, only because you see a lady in a bikini. Reminds me of my misspent youth. 5/7 I think its also a shooter.

So... took me a few years to finally finish this game as a part of my endless game backlog :) . I can definitely recommend this game to anyone who cares about 'old school' FPS like HL2 and the like. The game has a few annoyances like imprecise controls, a sense of floaty movement (like on skates) and some other minor issues but overall it is good fun. Of course it's pretty short because it was just supposed to be the first episode out of many but for the few hours it lasts it is quite entertaining. Not great but decent enough to give it a shot. Nice run & gun gameplay. Overall I'd probably rate it a 7/10 with one extra point just for the awesome title track 'What's the world come to' composed by Zak Belica and sung by Sarah Ravenscroft.

Sadly, you'll never get to see the ending to this story because the developer was bought up, and effectively squelched during the making of the following episode. So SiN Episodes: Emergence is effectively SiN 2, as a result. It's a shame because playing through this Source based sequel you'll find a lot of that fun actionsplotation you would have loved playing the original (Which comes with this game by the way which is why I recommend this). It's amped up now, and is a little less 'A to B shoot everything on the way' but still has that action star feel. Once again you're trying to track down a corrupt criminal CEO but now you've been poisoned. Play through this, and hope that someone competent secures the rights to finish this someday in our lifetime.

If I had to pick a single word to describe this game, it would be: Underwhelming. The entirety of the game is generic and bland. Weapons and gunplay are boring and uninspired, character models are generic and recycled, levels are completely and utterly linear, and movement and aiming feel... strange. Honestly, the graphics aren't that bad, but the whole game just feels old. Like Half Life 1 old.   Add to that the plot, which makes no sense to me, and spends entirely too much time without actually explaining anything, and the game comes across as utterly uncompelling. If you're a fan of the series, you may understand things better, and may consequently like the game more, but at this point I just have no interest in ever firing the game back up.
End my pain BLADE! Shoot me BLADE! PLEASE!

I had bought this at a Circuit City because I was bored and was curious about this whole 'SIN' thing. I didn't enjoy the demo of the original game much, but I was thinking more modern FPS design would help fix it! And I was pleasantly surprised. This is a leaner, shorter version of SIN without all the tedious level design (well, significantly less tedious anyway.) The scripted sequences are nice and it is fun to shoot the dudes in the head with your pistol. It's not much and it lasts about four hours, plus you're never going to ever get a sequel with this. Given all that, though, the work they must have put into this game and their subsequent closing down was the bellwether for the failure of the episodic model - too much work for too little payoff (and profit). Still, it's worth a playthrough.

SiN Episodes is a really polished example of early third-party source games. Pretty fun, straightfoward shooter.  The other game it comes bundled with, SiN (1998), is like a spiritual successor to Duke Nukem 3D, and to me will always be the real Duke Nukem Forever

Before playing SiN Episodes: Emergance, I would highly recommend playing the Original SiN to gain backstory on the events unfolding.   I highly recommend this game due to its gripping action, interesting charactrers, well put game design, great voice acting (which some of you may recognize), and the very simple, yet deadly weapons to choose from. However the cons to this sequal are: Lack of voice acting of Blade (the main hero), and interactive elements that were from the original game, such as: Computers, Panels. Other cons: Lack of Dark Environments from the original SiN, Electrka looks god damn gorgous but her face looks way different compared to SiN.   Other than that, Grab both games and have an old school pass through memory lane. And by the way...........'I'm gunna make you my ♥♥♥♥♥!'

(THIS IS FOR THE FIRST SIN GAME AND NOT EMERGENCE)  Still one of my favorite games of all time. SiN remains my favorite FPS ever created due to its interactivity, visuals, style, storyline and pure variety and fast paced fun to the gameplay. Sadly overshadowed by its competitor Half-Life even though SiN had done leaps and bounds more than the original Half-Life ever did. SiN kept the old school massive non-linear fast paced style of games such as Quake, Duke Nukem 3D, Blood and a bunch of other examples of the glory days of the fps.   But while keeping that old school style it brought in innovations such as vehicles, intelligent AI that could call for backup or run for cover, location based damage modeling, destructible environments, dynamic music, location based armour, and a whole slew of other achievements.   Compared to Half-Life the location variety, soundtrack and overall gameplay is leaps and bounds above it. It gives me a much more fast paced, fun, varied and non-linear experience. While Half-Life gave you a research facility, a desert and... a research facility. SiN gives you a bank, a factory, an underwater plant, a warehouse, an office building, a construction site, apartment buildings, mines and an assortment of other locations that I can't bring off the top of my head.   While Half-Life gave you slow tromps through a linear environment, SiN gave you large open levels with tonnes of hidden areas, secondary objectives and an incentive to explore for weapons, armour and ammo.   While Half-LIfe gave you limited interactivity, SiN gave you interactivity to the level of Duke3D with interactive computers used with DOS promps, destructible environments, secondary objectives or items that could drastically change future levels, along with an assortment of others.  Overall SiN shall forever remain one of my favorite FPS games of all time, it's a shame that it was ignored due to the release of Half-Life and the slew of bugs that plauged it until the first patch.   Rest in peace Ritual Entertainment, killed by the industry and being bought out by a casual company.
